resources.name: soil_data

fields.name: harvest_year
fields.title: Year in which crop harvested
fields.description: Year in which the wheat crop was harvested.

fields.name: plot
fields.title: Plot
fields.description: Original plots established in 1877

fields.name: sub_plot
fields.title: Sub-plot
fields.description: Some plots were divided into a and b halves to test different treatments from 1882.

fields.name: sub_sub_plot
fields.title: Sub sub-plot
fields.description: Some sub-plots were divided into i and ii halves, from 1905. Sub-plot a divided into i and ii (formerly known as aa), sub-plot b into i and ii (formerly known as bb), to test residual effects of fertilizer N.

fields.name: fertilizer_code
fields.title: Fertilizer and manure treatment code
fields.description: Code describing the fertilizer or manure applied in that harvest year

fields.name: lime_factor_level
fields.title: lime factor level
fields.description: Code for the lime treatment applied to that sub sub-plot

fields.name: fym_factor_level
fields.title: FYM factor level
fields.description: Code for the FYM factor level applied in that harvest year

fields.name: fym_amount
fields.title: Amount of FYM applied
fields.description: Approximate amount of FYM (farmyard manure) applied in that harvest year, fresh weight.  Top-dressed to winter wheat in February 1877-1906, ploughed in October before sowing 1907-1926.

fields.name: fym_n
fields.title: FYM N
fields.description: Approximate amount of N in the FYM applied in that harvest year. No fertilizer N applied after 1926

fields.name: rape_cake_factor_level
fields.title: Rape Cake factor level
fields.description: Code for the rape cake factor level applied in that harvest year. No rape cake applied after 1926

fields.name: rape_cake_n
fields.title: Rape cake N
fields.description: Amount of N applied as rape cake in that harvest year. No rape cake applied after 1926

fields.name: n_factor_level
fields.title: N factor level
fields.description: Code for the inorganic nitrogen fertilizer factor level applied in that harvest year. No fertilizer N applied after 1926

fields.name: fertilizer_n_amount
fields.title: Fertilizer N amount
fields.description: Total inorganic nitrogen fertilizer applied in this harvest year. This does not include N in FYM or rape cake. No fertilizer N applied after 1926

fields.name: p_factor_level
fields.title: P factor level
fields.description: Code for the phosphorous fertilizer factor level applied in that harvest year. No fertilizer P applied after 1926

fields.name: p_amount
fields.title: Fertilizer P amount
fields.description: Total inorganic phosphorous fertilizer applied in this harvest year. This does not include P in FYM or rape cake. No fertilizer P applied after 1926

fields.name: k_factor_level
fields.title: K factor level
fields.description: Code for the potassium fertilizer factor level applied in that harvest year. No fertilizer K applied after 1926

fields.name: k_amount
fields.title: Fertilizer K amount
fields.description: Total inorganic potassium fertilizer applied in this harvest year. This does not include K in FYM or rape cake. No fertilizer K applied after 1926

fields.name: na_factor_level
fields.title: Na factor level
fields.description: Code for the sodium fertilizer factor level applied in that harvest year. No fertilizer Na applied after 1926

fields.name: na_amount
fields.title: Fertilizer Na amount
fields.description: Total inorganic sodium fertilizer applied in this harvest year. This does not include Na in FYM or rape cake. No fertilizer Na applied after 1926

fields.name: mg_factor_level
fields.title: Mg factor level
fields.description: Code for the magnesium fertilizer factor level applied in that harvest year. No fertilizer Mg applied after 1926

fields.name: mg_amount
fields.title: Fertilizer Mg amount
fields.description: Total inorganic magnesium fertilizer applied in this harvest year. This does not include Mg in FYM or rape cake. No fertilizer Mg applied after 1926

fields.name: pH
fields.title: soil pH
fields.description: Soil pH measured in water by quinhydrone electrode, using the technique of the Soil Reaction Committee of the International Society of Soil Science. All earlier samples re-analysed by the same method in 1932.

fields.name: percent_c
fields.title: percent soil carbon
fields.description: Soil total carbon in air-dried ground soil (0.5mm sieve), measured by the Bangor method. There was very little free calcium carbonate in the soil, so total carbon is equivalent to organic carbon.

fields.name: percent_n
fields.title: percent soil nitrogen
fields.description: Soil total nitrogen in air-dried ground soil (0.5mm sieve), measured by Kjeldahl digestion

fields.name: c_n_ratio
fields.title: soil carbon to nitrogen ratio
fields.description: Ratio of total carbon to total nitrogen in the soil

fields.name: exch_ca
fields.title: exchangeable soil calcium
fields.description: Exchangeable calcium in air-dried ground soil (0.5mm sieve), extracted with 0.5M acetic acid, precipitating the calcium as oxalate at pH 4.0-4.3 and titrating the oxalate with permanganate. All earlier samples re-analysed by this method in 1932. Converted from meq/per cent (milliequivalents per 100 grams of soil) to mg/kg, using a conversion factor of 200.

fields.name: total_p
fields.title: total soil P
fields.description: Total soil P after fusion with sodium carbonate, by the Technicon AutoAnalyser, after the method of Salt (1968).  Analysed by Mattingly et al (1975), using archived soils from 1876, 1888, 1927 and 1932, main plots only.

fields.name: org_p_ignition
fields.title: organic P by ignition
fields.description: Organic P by igntion, method of Saunders and Williams (1955). Ground soil was ignited at 500-550 degress C for 2 hours and extracted with 0.2N H2SO4 for 2 hours at room temperature.  Organic P was estimated as the difference between soluble P extracted from ignited and unignited soil. Analysed by Mattingly et al (1975), using archived soils from 1876, 1888, 1927 and 1932, main plots only.

fields.name: org_p_extraction
fields.title: organic P by extraction
fields.description: Organic P by extraction, after Mehta et al (1955). Ground soil extracted with HCl, centrifuged then extracted with NaOH . Mattingly et al (1975) analysed archived soils from 1876, 1888, 1927 and 1932, main plots only.

fields.name: note_id
fields.title: Note identification
fields.description: Whether notes are applied or not. See notes_data for details

resources.title: soil data
resources.description: This is the main data table, containing the soil pH, percentage of total soil carbon (C) and nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P) and exchangeable calcium (Ca) in the topsoil (0-23cm) of the Woburn Continuous Wheat experiment, 1876 to 1932. Baseline measurements were taken in November 1876 before the start of the experiment. The soil was then sampled from each plot in 1888, 1927 and 1932. Selected plots were also sampled in  1898 and 1919.  Data expressed on an air-dried soil basis.  Also details of any fertilizer, manure and lime treatments applied in the sample year. No fertilizer, manure or lime applied after 1926. For full details of all fertilizer, manure and lime applications see Glendining, 2022a. Further detail on methods and sampling in fields_metadata and notes_data.  Carbon, N, pH and Ca data from Crowther, 1936; total and organic P data from Mattingly et al 1975. Winter wheat, sown in the autumn before the harvest year.

name: woburn-continuous-wheat-experiment-soil-data-1876-1932
title: Woburn Continuous Wheat Experiment soil data 1876-1932
description:
### Abstract
This dataset contains the soil pH, percentage of total soil carbon (C) nitrogen (N) phosphorus (P) and exchangeable calcium (Ca) in the topsoil (0-23cm) of the Woburn Continuous Wheat experiment, 1876 to 1932. Baseline measurements were taken in November 1876 before the start of the experiment. The soil was then sampled from each plot in 1888, 1927 and 1932. Selected plots were also sampled in 1898 and 1919. The dataset also contains details of the fertilizer, manure and lime treatments applied 1876-1926. No fertilizer, manure or lime was applied after 1926. 
The soil at Woburn contained little free calcium carbonate, and soil pH was 6.1 in 1876. Consequently, where ammonium sulphate was applied (plots 2, 5 and 8) the soil soon became acidic and yields declined markedly within 20 years. These were the first experiments in the UK where lime was applied to try to correct soil acidity.

Data from Crowther (1936) and Mattingly et al (1975), see Resource Provenance.
### Methods
The Woburn Continuous Wheat experiment originally had 11 plots (1-11), with different fertilizer and manure treatments. Some plots were divided into sub-plots (a and b) from 1882, and into sub sub-plots (i and ii) from 1905, to test different treatments, mainly with and without lime. Full details are given in Related Documents.
- **Soil pH** measured in water by quinhydrone electrode. Analysed in 1932 (earlier samples re-analysed).
- **Soil C** total soil carbon, measured by the Bangor method. There is very little free calcium carbonate, so this is equivalent to soil organic carbon. 
- **Soil N** total soil nitrogen, measured by the Kjeldahl method.
- **Exch Ca** exchangeable calcium extracted with 0.5M acetic acid. Analysed in 1932. 
- **Total P** total soil P by Technicon AutoAnalyser after fusion with sodium carbonate, method of Salt (1968). 
- **Org P_ignition** Organic P by ignition, method of Saunders and Williams (1955). 
- **Org P_extraction** Organic P by extraction with HCl then NaOH, method of Mehta et al (1955).
### Technical Info
Data expressed on air-dried soil basis.  Ground soil, passed through a 0.5mm sieve. Soil samples in 1876, 1888 and 1898 taken with sample box 15cm x 15cm x 23cm deep, composite of three holes. 1927 sample cut by spade 23cm deep, 4-5 holes per plot combined into composite samples. 1932 sample taken with a small semi-cylindrical sampler, 20 holes per plot, soil combined into composite samples.
### Other
The soil was relatively fertile at the start of the experiment, thought to be due to large FYM applications to the preceding arable rotation.  Soil fertility generally declined, except in plots given FYM. 
The high C:N ratio of some wheat plots (eg Plot 7 and 8a) was due to the presence of coal and charcoal in the soil (Crowther, 1936, p 319). 

**Methods of Analysis references:**
- Mehta, N.C., Legg, J.O., Goring, C.A.I. and Black, C.A. (1954). Determination of organic phosphorus in soils. I. Extraction method. Soil Science Society of America, Proceedings 18, 443-449 
- Salt, P.D. (1968) The automatic determination of phosphorus in extracts of soils made with 0.5M sodium hydrogen carbonate and 0.01M calcium chloride. Chemistry and Industry, 584-586. 
- Saunders, W.M.H. and Williams, E.G. (1955). Observations on the determination of total organic phosphorus in soils. Journal of Soil Science, 6: 254-267.
### Provenance
- Soil C, N, pH and Ca data from Crowther, E. M. (1936) "Chapter XXII. The soils of the Woburn plots. ", Fifty years of the field experiments at the Woburn Experimental Station. Rothamsted Monographs on Agricultural Science. (Russell E.J. and Voelcker J.A. (eds) - Longmans, Green and Co,), No. 7., 315-345. 
- Total and organic P data from Mattingly et al, 1975, main plots only.
### Quality
In accordance with the Joint Code of Practice for Research at Rothamsted, data processing in e-RA follow rigorous standard operating procedures to ensure the quality and correctness of data collected in the field through to depositing in the e-RA database. To ensure quality control during data inputting, the data sets were typed on two separate occasions (double data entry). During the second typing (verification) the data values were compared with those typed on the earlier occasion, and any discrepancies were resolved before verification continued. This procedure also set out how to handle situations where the written records were illegible or ambiguous. This procedure avoided visual checking of data, which can be very inaccurate.
